--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico <magicq=
uartz@...> wrote:
>
> With a gentile smile, Tucson returns the kiss and hol=
ds his wing over them to provide a moment alone with Talon.  After the kiss=
 he lowers his wing and notices that a collection of small creatures surrou=
nding him and Talon .  Yet they do so in a fashion of admiration rather tha=
n hostility.  Tucson looks to them curiously.
> 
> " I'm not sure why these=
 creatures are curious about us but it appears as if they're here to admire=
 rather than attack.  I wonder...  "
> 
> He stands up and gets back into b=
east mode, and sits down once more.  The creatures draw closer to him and s=
it beside him and Talon.  It was clear that the Silver Dragon was a source =
of comfort to these creatures, but that was about to change once he and Tal=
on left for Cybertron.  It was a massive guilt slammed upon his heart.  Yet=
 how could he get the animals to understand that he had to leave them in su=
ch a short time?  He was now their guardian and they were looking up to him=
 for protection.  
> 
> " Talon, these creatures remember the old dragon th=
at sought to their protection and realize that I have taken his place.  It'=
s as I thought, they aren't aware of who we really are, and where we are fr=
om.  They will not understand that we must leave them shortly, for good, an=
d Primus knows what will happen to them once we leave. ...  Talon, I hear s=
omething coming. It's not a Predacon but it's a fairly large creature."
> 
=
> Not far from them, Tucson spots the scales of a rather large reptile, tha=
t appears to be fishing in the stream next to them.  He watches attentively=
 and at that moment, the creature lifts its head.  It was another dragon.  =
Yet this one was a bit smaller than he was, but the same coloration.  He ta=
kes note of its slender shape.  It was female.  She looks to him as he look=
s to her.  She slowly approaches him and they look gently to each other lik=
e brother and sister.  In draconic vocalization, Tucson explains who he is =
and his dilemma.  She intern rumbles back and bows her head.  She nods as h=
e does.  It was their way of communicating as Tucson looks back to Talon.
>=
 
> " Apparently the old dragon has family here.  They are scattered but th=
ey exist.  And she said that she will protect these creatures and this land=
 along with her brethren for as long as they live.  And she wishes us good =
luck on our journey."
> 
> With that, the dragoness leaves them peacefully =
to enjoy their time together.  With a gentile groan, the creatures too, dep=
art. It was truly a spiritual moment for both of them.

> > > Tucson holds Talon ge=
ntly with an arm around her shoulders. He looks up and then back to her.
> =
> > 
> > > " Like a branch on a tree that has broken off during a storm and=
 regrows in a different direction than it had been, before it had broken of=
f. I know exactly how you feel. I feel the same way. At one time, I was bli=
nd, rolled on four wheels and I always seemed to be an Autobot rebel. I fou=
ght along side with my comrades but I wasn't good at following orders. I wa=
s well grounded but lost at the same time. Then, I met you and things began=
 to change on a more positive note. You may not believe this, but you helpe=
d me to find my path, and you saw me on the right road and guided me to my =
true fate. Soon afterwards, I became a Prime, acquired seventeen more wheel=
s, and almost looked like Optimus Prime, yet different. But one thing didn'=
t change, I was still battling blindness off and on. Then, a third change, =
due to extensive damage to my previous form, which could not be repaired, I=
 was guided to my final evolution, this one. All of these things wouldn't h=
ave come about if I had never met you. And I wouldn't have it any other way=
. Talon, I will miss this planet as much as you are, and hopefully we can t=
ell our offspring all about this planet and it's wondrous varieties of life=
 that live here."
> > > 
> > > The rodent climbs down and drops a nut into =
his hand, and chatters to him.
> > > 
> > > " This is for us to keep? Thank=
 you, we will take good care of it."
> > > 
> > > He places the nut in Talo=
n's hand.
> > > 
> > > " I think we have a way to bring back a small remind=
er of this planet. Let's see if we can encourage it to grow on ours."

py look on his face, Tucson walks with Talon, down the corridor and out to =

ding to the old dragon's cave. But the path itself carries a serene atmosph=
ere as a gentile stream ripples over glistening river rocks while dragonfli=
es dodge the current of the water. And now, for the first time, Tucson coul=
d actually enjoy it visually as well as harmonically.

> > >=

ld will remain as pure as it is now. But there's more that I want to show y=
ou."

es and points upward.

des you from the heat of the sun. It provides shelter and protection, yet i=

when he was my Sensai. See things with a different perspective and not alwa=
ys what everyone else sees. Here, I'll show you. "
